metadata.title: Effect of fin and hybrid nano-particles on solid process in hexagonal triplex Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage System

This research deals with solidification procedure of phase-changing material (PCM) in a Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage System (LHTESS). Rectangular fin made of copper and triplex container are utilized in this study and also different
volume fractions of Hybrid Nano-Particles (HNP) ( 2TiO -Go ) are added to the water. In present research, water is regarded as PCM. The purpose of this research is to inquire the effect of HNPs, fins and shape factor of nanoparticles on acceleration of the solidification process. As an innovation, a new hexagonal geometry along with fins is employed in LHTESS. Galerkin Finite Element Method (GFEM) is applied to solve the governing equations and coding is carried out by an open source application. Results indicated that applying fins and HNPs reduces the full solidification time up to 12% and also using lamina shaped HNPs reduces the full solidification time up to 4% more than brick shaped.
Keywords: Triplex LHTESS; HNP; Solid process; PCM; Fin; GFEM.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Many researchers have conducted on different methods of increasing the efficiency of heat transfer according to the need. One of the many methods that has been paid a great amount of attention, is the usage of PCMs. PCMs possess the ability to store a great amount of energy as latent heat in constant-phase transient temperature. In addition to that, they can also be used as passive heat storages. The positive properties of PCMs include their ability to be used as a source with constant temperature, negligible temperature drop, suitable melting point, chemical stability, low steam pressure and high energy density. Due to these strengths, PCMs are used in different industries such as thermal storage of solar energy [1-6], thermal management of electronic devices [6-8], thermal storages in buildings [9,10], cooling of engines [11,12], etc. The biggest weakness of PCMs, is the low thermal conductivity which hinders high rate of charge and discharge of heat flux. The first researches on PCMs were conducted by Raymond and Telks in the 1940s [13]. This field was not paid much attention until the 1970s [14]. Using PCMs in LHTESS, creates a balance between stored energy and the energy offered. These systems store heat while melting and release it during the solidification. Wu et al. [15] suspended a small amount of nanoparticles in molten paraffin and created a new nanofluidic PCM that increased the heat transfer rate. Tian and Zhao [16] conducted experimental research to study

melting/solidification process using Paraffin wax RT58 as PCM with metal foam for enhanced heat transfer. They discovered that adding the metal foam, enhances heat transfer during the melting process, and the liquid phase by 3 to 10 times. Faghani et al. [17] researched about the effect of various shapes for the shell and tube in heat exchangers equipped with PCMs and found out that the shape of both shells and tubes play a role in the melting process. Pourakbar and Darzi [18] investigated the melting and solidification of PCM in a cylinder with different shapes for the shell and also different arrangements for the tubes. They concluded that the number and arrangements of the inner tubes can enhance the melting rate and the solidification rate by 70% and 40%, respectively. The efficiency of thermal systems is generally increased by two methods: Passive and Active methods. In the Passive method, there is no need for external energy. Fins are used in this method. These fins are placed in different arrangements and made form different materials, to obtain heat penetration and depth, which in turn increases the efficiency of the system. A good example for the passive method is the use of “spread surfaces”. Tiari et al. [19] performed a numerical study on LHTESS infused with high melting point PCM, in a finned thermal tube. They concluded that longer fins lead to higher wall base-temperature, and does not have a considerable effect on discharging time. Also, by increasing the number of fins, the solidification rate and the base-temperature of the container increase . A numerical study by Lohrasbi et

al. [20] was aimed at investigating LHTESS infused with Nano-Enhanced PhaseChanging Materials (NEPCM) in a finned thermal tube. Their results show that using V-shaped fins increases the discharge rate by 4.214 times; in compare to the cases without fins. A study to enhance solidification in LHTESS shell and tube, using triangular fins was done by Liu et al [21]. The results of their research proved that the use of triangular fins, decreases the solidification time by 38.3% in compare to the typical, rectangular fins.
Hosseinizadeh et al. [22] used a numerical approach to investigate NEPCM in a spherical container. Their results prove that the PCMs infused with nanoparticles, offer good performance as thermal energy storages. Nabeal et al. [23] conducted a numerical and experimental study, aimed to research about the melting procedure of NEPCM in a two-dimensional cylinder with a constant heat flux. This study explained that the use of nanoparticles increases the effective thermal conduction in the PCM and enhances melting/solidification process. A numerical study by Sebti et al. [24] on solidification in concentric annuli filled with NEPCM proved that suspended nanoparticles increase the heat transfer rate and decrease the solidification time, significantly. Hosseinzadeh et al. [25] conducted a numerical study on the solidification procedure in an LHTESS containing Al2O3 – CuO Hybrid Nano-Enhanced Phase-Changing Materials (HNEPCM) which proved that by increasing the volume fraction of PCMs ,the solidification rate increases 24.1%

[26] was directed to investigate the effects of single nanoparticles, as well as HNPs on the melting process of NEPCM in a square cavity, and their study shows that the liquid fraction and solid-liquid interface are greatly under the effect of the volume fraction of the nanoparticles, as well as the thermal conductivity parameter. A work by Hosseinzadeh et al. [27]
was aimed to study the effects of 2TiO -Cu hybrid nanoparticles and tree-like branding, in presence of thermal radiation, and their results show that the use of tree-like branching with higher bifurcating angles, speeds up the solidification process due to deeper thermal diffusion. Sciacovelli et al. [28] worked on maximization of performance of a PCM latent heat storage system with innovative fins, and concluded that optimized fins improve the system efficiency. Optimized bifurcating fins lead to 24% increase in the efficiency of the system.
In present study, an innovative hexagonal geometry is applied in a triplex tube and also the effect of extended surfaces and HNPs on solidifications process is investigated and the governing equations are solved by GFEM.

sections.heading: 3. Numerical Method
sections.text:
The GFEM is employing PDE integrals to form discredited equations in mesh nodes. This method solves equations by cubic interpolation over triangles and nodal amounts are placed on the corners of cells. Definitions are replaced to form the Galerkin couple matrix and segregate the dependents from the variables. Integration is applied on cells and equations are formed, based on variables and Newton-Raphson method is used to solve the final equations and it employs backward difference technique to solve the equations containing time-based

integration. As it is demonstrated in Fig. 2 the solidification procedure is simulated by adaptive grid refinement. At unsteady conditions, this method is utilized to refine meshes that had instant changes in their initial values.
In this study, the numerical method is utilized by comparing the equations based on GFEM with former empirical study published by Ismaeil et al. [29]. Fig. 3 shows that this comparison contains maximum error of 5 percent. As a conclusion, assumption of discarding the convection terms is logical.

sections.heading: 4.1. Comparison between LHTESS with and without fins for pure PCM
sections.text:
Temperature and solidification contours for with fins and without fins modes can be observed in Fig. 4 for three different time steps (20, 100 and 300 (s)). There is equal amount of PCM in container in these two investigated modes. Results show that adding fins to the container causes an increment in heat penetration and heat exchange area which causes more decrement in temperature compared to without fins mode and also increases the solidification rate. Comparison of solidification rate between with fins and without fins container is shown in Fig. 5 in three different time steps. It can be obtained from the results that when the fins are added, more volume of container is solidified and it is obvious that over time, solidification rate is increased.

Fig. 7-a shows the simultaneous effect of HNEPCM with volume fraction amount
of 0.025, with fin and nanoparticles ( 2TiO -Go ) as methods of increasing heat transfer in three different time steps on the temperature contour. The results illustrate that adding fins and nanoparticles to the container have a great effect on temperature reduction. Also Fig. 7-b shows the effect of HNPs and fins on solidification process. As results demonstrate when the fins and nanoparticles are added to the container solidification rate is strongly increased due to heat transfer coefficient and penetration increment, also heat exchange area amount is much higher with fins.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In present work, a numerical simulation is applied on solidification process of PCM with HNPs in Hexagonal Triplex LHTESS. Copper fins are added and HNPs are dispersed into PCM. These additions are carried out to enhance heat transfer. The main results of current study point that:
1. The solidification rate is increased up to 8% due to applying fins on the triplex LHTESS. 2. Dispersing HNPs into PCM causes 3% increment in the solidification rate. 3. The solidification rate has been increased 12% by applying HNPs in PCM and fins in the LHTESS simultaneously 4. Employing lamina shaped HNPs have been caused the solidification rate increment 4%.
